p: Ethnobotanical surveys were conducted between June 2017 to February 2018 and February to April 2019. A total of 188 informants, including herbalists, traditional health practitioners, and curing healers were interviewed. They were selected using the snowball method [ 10, 29, 30] and surveyed using semi-structured interviews. Following Thomas et al. [ 31], plant photos were used to complete interviews and to check the respondentsâ€™ ability to recognize the plants they use. We used photos depicted in Pauwels et al. [ 32] as well as their own photos taken during preparatory field visits in the study area.
